Yeah. Okay. So, this is CAN.
CAN is a modal verb. We use "can"
+ the base verb to talk about abilities.

What are you able to do? What can you do?
I can play the piano, and I can jump rope.

Notice how we stress the base verb, the
main verb.

I can play. I can jump.
So, especially in fast speech "can"

will often sound like /k…ôn/.
I can do it. I can see.
I can go.

The negative form is "cannot" or the
contraction "can't."

Repeat after me.
Let's stress the negative form.
I can't go.

I can't hear.
I can't tell you.
To talk about past abilities we use "could."

The negative: "could not" And the
contraction: "couldn't."
We use these forms to talk about
things we were able to do in the past. Listen.

Okay. So, this is "can." Now think of the
past.

Can-could. So, we think of the past. Um,
let's think about ourselves as little girls.

Let's remember how we form questions. We use

verb + subject. Can you go?
Can they come? Yes-no questions
use rising intonation. Listen to how my voice
goes up at the end. Can you see?
Can he come?
Can they pay?
Can she dance?

Can you visit me?
Can you repeat that?
Can we talk about this?
When you ask questions for information,
use falling intonation. Listen to my voice go down.
Who can help? When can you come?
Why can't he come?
How can you text so fast?
Where can I buy one?
